Blog.post: Sometime back in March I guess, I made my first ever trip to a yarn store - urlLink The Woolie Ewe. I was so overwhelmed by all the beautiful yarns that I didn't know what to do. But I really wanted to buy something, so I bought two balls of this yarn from the Plymouth Italian Collection. It's called Siam. Go urlLink here and click on Siam to see what it looks like. The yarn was on sale for 50% off, and it had such pretty colors and fluffy bits sticking out that I couldn't resist. I wasn't sure if I had enough to make a scarf out of it, but I took a chance and paired it with one strand of Caron Simply Soft in black and a size N hook. It's made in single crochet with chain 1 spaces. Luckily, I did have enough to make the scarf with fringe. It ended up being 3" wide and 60" long with fringe. It's really thick also. I don't know think anyone on my Christmas list would like this scarf, so I'm going to keep it!

This is my first original pattern design I submitted i to link w/text urlLink Crochet Me but I don't know if it will get accepted. So here is the pattern for my ruffled scarf: Materials Needed: J hook (6.0 mm) One 3 ounce skein of LionBrand Wool-Ease in Blush Heather (or your choice of worsted weight yarn) Finished Size: Approximately 2 1/2 inches wide by 43 inches long Instructions: Ch 120. Row 1: Sc in 2nd chain from hook and each chain across. Ch 2 and turn. Row 2: Dc in each Sc across. Ch 2 and turn. Row 3: Make 2 Dc in each Dc across. Ch 2 and turn. Row 4: Make 3 Dc in each Dc across. Finish off and weave in ends.

These are all going to be edged in black and then sewn together to make a scarf. Finally, a place to keep all my crochet accessories. I used urlLink this pattern.

I'm in some kind of crocheting slump. Every time I start a pattern I end up stopping and ripping it out because I'm either disatisfied with the way the pattern looks or with the way the yarn looks in the pattern. I think I want to make my grandma a shawl for Christmas, but I've looked at every shawl pattern on the internet and in my books and none of them are appealing to me. Sigh. Maybe I should just use my cotton yarn to make her a potholder or a dishcloth . . . The only thing I have been succesful making are some little granny squares. I think I'm going to edge them in black and put them end to end to make a scarf for someone. Christmas Update: 6 down, 5 to go (if I can ever settle on patterns/stitches for them)
